author: sky.cactus
content: Even if the specifications are translated, the English ones will always be the official source of truth.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm curious how many developers/potential developers we have who don't speak English but are working or want to work on Ethereum?

author: sky.cactus
content: While there are *definitely* many end-users who don't speak English that we should be targeting, I'm less confident there is a large collection of developers who don't speak English.

author: sky.cactus
content: This belief stems from the fact that it is relatively hard to learn to program in the first place without speaking English, since documentation for every language and most libraries is in English.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm sure there exists non-native speakers who would benefit from translation, and there may be very small number of individuals who don't speak English at all who would benefit.  But we should make sure we are weighing that against the production and maintenance costs of translating.

author: sky.cactus
content: The maintenance in particular worries me a bit.  Maintaining translations can become pretty difficult, especially if you want them integrated into the primary process in some way.

author: samwilsn
content: As far as I know Sphinx supports internationalization, so EELS should be able to support this should we pursue it.
